everything is possible if one is willing to alienate all factions more or less equally. in fact, the more aligned you are internally, the more misaligned you'll be externally, because it'll be impossible for you to fit any generic mould well. so you'll always remain an outsider and never fully assimilate in any place or culture ever.

but no one is willing to stand alone and alienate people, so you get safety-maxxing tribal behaviour.

@tsawrub you take either too far and you'll get the opposite: totalitarian regimes are quickly followed by anarchy and anarchies/flat "everyone is equal" hierarchies naturally breed totalitarianism in their own way

yes, abstract plane vs concrete plane problem. the left lacks a material grounded perspective, while the right thinks material might is right and loses perspective that way

i wouldn't say anything about who is winning though. that's debatable, as tech and creativity are fundamentally left leaning while power is right leaning and they both feed into each other all the time
@Infinite_Outlaw but the self-fashioned arjuna today is a bhogi, not a yogi

the core difference i see between the two camps is the left exists in the abstract idea plane while the right exists in the concrete material plane. being in the abstract plane pushes notions like creativity, innovation, culture, and more fluid and abstract constructs, while being in the physical plane pushes notions like sacrifice, hardwork, pulling yourself up by your bootstraps, protecting your family and community, establishing physical boundaries, etc.

the left often transgresses boundaries and material context in favour of utopian and clean ideas, while the right is extremely averse to such trespassing because it's rooted in the soil. but it also makes it more totalitarian, principled and imposing locally, while the left is more totalitarian in the realm of ideas, while not being principled in real interactions. the left cares about changing the world; context doesn't matter, only ideas do, while the right doesn't give two fucks about anything outside of its own province and cares about proximate material and social considerations.

there's no one fully left or right wing person, just like there's no single absolutely masculine man or feminine woman. but there are a bunch of core traits/qualities you can associate with the two.

it's a general observation about trade offs and how you start respecting them as you grow older. the young liberal has no appreciation for natural tradeoffs or the price one needs to pay due to her sheltered life. you only realise them as you grow older, and then the costs of living by the same values start to make little sense to those who were never sincere about them to begin with, because a real principle will always require giving things up. and many realise they don't have it in them to give those things up.

but insofar as it says one ought to be dogmatic and conservative as they grow old, that's not necessary. it depends on how much one is willing to give up to stay true to themselves. a conservative is naturally someone who has a lot to lose, and is thus conservative.

but it isn't a problem at all. i can afford to sleep or stay awake whenever i want. if i couldn't, i wouldn't, and this "problem" would be solved on its own.

why? because i can afford it. if i started working full time again, my sleep schedule would quickly resume its prior consistency.

a behaviour that has slowly but surely internalized in the past year is to ignore any claims the present mood makes about what mustafa should or should not be doing henceforth in the future because of what mustafa is feeling right now.¬†present emotional state is a terrible oracle for future preferences or capabilities and the future itself is a total fabrication. self¬†tries to escape the discomfort of now by projecting a solution onto tomorrow, but in doing so, ends up not resolving the present.¬†it's like trying to fix a leaky faucet by planning to become a plumber next year,¬†sketching plans for a future self who will somehow possess the exact tools that the present self claims to lack, while water pools at one's feet, unattended.¬†the mind kids itself that calling out some future fix somehow takes care of what's happening right now, because the mind can't sit still in the now, it doesn't live in the now, only in yesterday or tomorrow.¬†it exists exclusively in memory or projection, never in the real.¬†so the more the self surrenders instead of trying to fix or manage how it feels,¬†the faster the feeling tends to move through and out. it naturally¬†dissipates.¬†i feel awful now stays just that. it doesn't become i'll feel awful forever or better cancel my life or quit this hellsite for good.¬†there's no executive self multiplying the difficulty by resisting the resistance itself,¬†no boss-self piling narrative friction on top of the raw sensation.

anything a competent rival can match in 3-6 months is not an edge and there's no edge to aesthetics today at all. look at the cluely genre of marketing for instance. all consequential branding today emerges from the product quality itself, never the messaging around it. at best, good aesthetics are cognitive ergonomics: they compress values and affordances so users form correct expectations quickly. in crowded markets, such legibility is a coordination edge. it can attract the right users and partners, which then improves feedback loops and product quality. but aesthetics without substance is ephemeral and gets co-opted quickly. you want aesthetics fused with product taste and execution. that taste compounds because it guides a thousand micro‚Äëdecisions no one can copy in 3-6 months.

what i often see is dhandho-minded people chasing large TAM without ever thinking about what will uniquely differentiate them or if they even have a very high internal bar for the product or service they're trying to build. because without his high bar, it's quite unlikely that you'll actually be competitive in any meaningful sense. a high bar is a cost until it shows up as pricing power and retention. without a small monopoly built on a secret, you‚Äôre renting customers from ads and the market will arbitrage away any dhandha you thought you had.

thinking about that segment of the dwarkesh‚Äìkarpathy convo where andrej talks about how high the bar is for 1:1 tutoring and how it's not the right time to build an AI tutor because of that bar because LLMs are nowhere close to the kind of situational-sensing an experienced human tutor has. i find this¬†gut-level grasp of quality standards and¬†appreciation for how high the bar is in anything you do quite missing in non-craftspersons. they don't grok the sheer complexity of building something right and the fractal nature of quality decisions. it's a fundamentally different mental model and i've found this intuition gap to be unbridgeable in practice.¬†they think you're being a pessimist, but what you really have is just a calibrated sense for where the bar actually sits, and you recognize most people are optimizing for entirely different ends that have little to do with craft.

maybe it's just that¬†people respond to their incentives and time horizons. if you don‚Äôt change incentives to reward long-duration quality, a craftsperson's calibration will always look like pessimism to others. it's either that or you¬†reduce the problem until you can exceed it with taste.

@nadinjayk same

you need distribution because there's no upper cap on the cost it takes to produce good things, but there's is a strict upper cap on the price anyone will pay for something, no matter how good

production costs can scale almost infinitely; you can spend $1 million, $100 million, or $1 billion making a movie, drug, or building. the quality might improve with more resources (though often with diminishing returns), but there's essentially no ceiling on what you could spend.

however, willingness to pay hits a hard wall. even if a movie cost $500 million to make and is objectively incredible, most people won't pay more than maybe $20 to see it. a life-saving drug might cost billions in R&D, but there's still a limit to what any individual or even healthcare system will pay per dose.

this is why distribution/scale becomes existential rather than just helpful. if you spend $100 million making something, you must reach enough people to amortize those costs below their willingness-to-pay threshold. can't just make it 10x better and charge 10x more. that market often doesn't exist.

also perhaps explains why openai is doing ehat it's doing. building AGI has essentially no upper bound on costs (compute, data, talent, infrastructure keep scaling), but there is an upper bound on what users will pay. even their $200/month ChatGPT Pro plan is probably losing money atp. so they're desperately pursuing distribution and new revenue models like advertising. they'll do essentially anything to get revenue from more people at lower price points, because the alternative would be to only serve customers willing to pay thousands per month, but that market is tiny relative to their cost structure. they *need* hundreds of millions of users generating smaller amounts each. they need all the capital they can get.

this is one of those sayings that is spiritually true, but will quickly fall apart if you poke at it with facts.

truth/ authority/ authenticity/ originality has no prescribed shape. it is fundamentally chaotic. and for the self that operates as a pattern-recognition machine constantly scanning for more patterns to reinforce its own stability, truth is existential vertigo.¬†a man who compulsively stacks routines upon routines to maintain coherence fears dissolution.¬†but genuinely novel and authoritative work can only crystallize from this disorienting space.

the ‚Äúclean desk‚Äù is merely a material proxy for a specific cognitive style, but it's not the style itself. people who compulsively pattern-match and routine-build (the sort of homeostatic tendency that manifests as desk-tidying) will hit walls with authentic innovation because they're fortifying against entropy and flux. but this doesn't mean workspace chaos = creative genius. the clean desk isn't the core dysfunction, it's the rigidity-bias it signals which blocks originality.
opportunity cost mindset is hazardous to any enquiry, for the psychological cost of things you know and can measure will always exceed the cost of what you don't know and can't measure

a research lab, or any state of sincere and open enquiry, in general, is an abundance phenomenon. a state of lack engenders predictability and goal-chasing, never real exploration. innovation is wasteful, but you cannot afford waste.

if you're spending 5 minutes on the prompt for both 20-min work and 20-hour work, something is wrong and you're trusting the ai with way too much autonomy.

few understand that the time you spend prompting needs to scale linearly as a fraction of the time you'd have spent doing the work yourself. something that would take you one hour to produce yourself may need you to spend far less time on the prompt than something that'd take you ten. for the latter, even spending one full hour just working and reworking the prompt + plan is a worthwhile investment of time. you're still saving nine hours.

remember that most of the tacit knowledge and creative detail still needs to come from you and it has to go in the prompt.

many of the fields are simple dropdowns. essentially, the key lies in extracting as detailed a prompt from the user as possible to generate the story. it's inspired by how good midjourney prompts look: they have a premise + a bunch of technical descriptors. the more detailed these descriptors are, the more you can control the output. i've discovered that the same prompting style applies to generating text-based artifacts as well.

@krishnanrohit here, you'll see the suggestions for the central question aren't really good because i've only entered the premise and nothing else. so the trick, as i've discovered, also lies in which fields to fill in first and which to fill in later. https://t.co/g7eaX9DPyH

it's quite simple. i jotted out the basic elements that make up a story and designed a long form around it. and the form fields themselves use ai, with only the premise being a mandatory field. so, for instance, if i enter a premise and a few more settings i have clarity on, i could generate content options for any other field based on the existing content in the other fields. and i can do this for all fields if i wanted to. so it gives me perfect control over what i already know about the story, and what i need more help on. what's more interesting is the more fields you fill in the form, the better the ai suggestions for the remaining text fields get.
@krishnanrohit does it work for longer stories? when i tried it, it felt like it was designed for parents generating storybooks for their kids

@krishnanrohit generated this ~20,000 word story entirely w/ claude and a story generator app i vibecoded on gemini canvas. 
https://t.co/5klp7Tfe0T

unslop would have a small market if most good writers weren't so anti-ai. but as it stands, there's no market for it. it is built for me and me alone, and i'm not even interested in making it public. no one really cares about taking their writing from an 8 to a 9. and judging by how good vanilla gpt and claude writing are getting, few would demand any better. good enough is good enough
i don't know about others, but my intent is to communicate what i wish to communicate in the most effective and beautiful way i can muster, it isn't to be known as an organic, free-range writer.

if you go through this thread, you'll realize that vanilla lllm writing might've been far better than it is today if writers weren't so anti-ai-pilled and parochial in their views.

there's nothing wrong with thought except the fact that most of it has its roots in the lie called "the self." thought is extremely useful, it has given us all our science and technology. but the fact that it doesn't stay limited to the world and also keeps building and narrativizing on top of an untruth we call the self is why thought creates problems. there's nothing wrong with thought, everything wrong with the belief called the self that we take for granted. it is what creates all psychological suffering.

@recurshawn the moment thought enters, self-concept enters, and along with it, a bunch of things it likes to believe about itself and what's good and what's bad. this js where the moviebrain operates.

no mediation by thought. if you saw a snake in your bedroom, you'd immediately recoil and act. if you found yourself approaching the precipice of a cliff, you'd instinctively step back. this requires no analysis or mediation by the self and its concepts/narratives. it's just the body doing its thing.
@recurshawn feeling isn't narrative; it may arise due to one or more of the many narratives that constitute the self, but it always points true towards honest intent/motive. it isn't narrative.

observe yourself not with words but with how you live. how you live is the most comprehensive account of your life and motivations. and do this for a long enough period and you will realize you don't exist at all, there's only a flux of motivating drives puppeteering you at any given point in time. the strongest drives direct the course of your life.

this mode isn‚Äôt passive either. life still asks things of you, but the response isn‚Äôt forced, it‚Äôs given. you don‚Äôt drag yourself into action; action draws itself out of you. it feels lighter, even joyful, compared to the heavy grind of will.

by giving up trying to live better, life starts living you better.

everything happens, but without the interference of the manager-self trying to orchestrate and control everything. this  is not mechanical dullness; it‚Äôs a much finer attunement, because it‚Äôs no longer filtered through compulsive rationalization. it‚Äôs closer to instinct, to play, to spontaneity.

and then what happens when you come to a stop? you naturally start doing what is genuinely necessary for your life. all the real forces in the situation start puppeteering you and you essentially enter autopilot mode. what‚Äôs necessary begins to self-perpetuate.

so, how do i get out of this? what do i do? 

what i consciously do will not be the real thing. so what do i do?

so that brings you to a stop, by design. when the intellect realizes it cannot fix itself because the fixer is the problem, it collapses into silence.

when you realize the futility of logic and just the recursive and paradoxical nature of logic itself, you actually are allowing what is natural to you come forth without any rationalization, because you arrived at a point where you know that all rationalization is false because who is the one doing the rationalizing? 

the very self that is the flawed self is doing the rationalizing. so it is a logical double bind.
zen koans are designed to paralyse the rationalizing faculty, so that the only thing left is direct perception, instinct, intent, and embodied knowing. they are designed to kickstart autopilot mode.

paradoxes aren't traps but doorways. when logic collapses under its own weight, you‚Äôre left with a felt sense that is more real than any of your philosophy. the paradox isn't meant to be answered with correct propositions or introduce even more logic, but to run your mind out of moves until something more direct and honest appears that recognizes the totality of the situation/context/intent and all the competing forces seeking resolution. easy to put blinders on yourself with logic and philosophy. not only are words not the thing, they are not even comprehensive enough to describe the thing in its totality. this is where all sophistry happens.

the best and easiest way of recognizing the futility of logic in self-knowledge is via the paradox and the logical double-bind. let logic collapse onto itself to let what's embodied come through. logic disembodies people like nothing else does. it makes them miserable, puts them out of touch with their own reality. it's no surprise why masters across eras have used the logical double-bind as a truth-telling device.

what you're confusing here is reality with social media. on social media, words are rarely directly targeted at you, they're just expressed in the ether. this, at least, is true for me. so it's a mirror of sorts. how you choose to respond to something that wasn't even about you is totally your doing. it reflects you more than it reflects me.

yes, there is an intent to reveal more than words can allow, so it is manipulative in that sense. but i don't need anything from anyone.

but this doesn't apply to interpersonal relationships irl, where manipulation is specifically targeted towards certain people for some petty ends. that's the manipulation i avoid and would love if everyone developed the ability to spot it and avoid it. that's why i put so much emphasis on saying fuck you and burning bridges.

you only know me here, you don't know me irl.

"too self-aware" is a state far away for almost everyone. maybe you are too self-aware and don't need it *now*, after having gone through those motions. but you shouldn't lie about the fact that the self-awareness has played a role in you returning home. truth is simple, but the path there is fraught with self-awareness and its ironies.

the one big advantage barbells have is they allow loading yourself with a lot more weight than kettlebells do. but kettlebells are far more functional than barbells. more representative of hauling real world loads. they're not the best representative or anything, just closer than barbells. they engage muscles barbell training will never let you know even existed.

largely, it's just the variety of movements you can do based on your skill level that's really fun. i get bored easily, so variety and novelty helps. also newer muscles get engaged every time you try a new movement or complex. barbells train the same few muscular groups over and over again.

ai will never be good enough for motivated reasoners. they will keep shifting the goalposts. everything feels flat if someone tells you it's ai-generated. yet, everyday, ai written posts from VCs and founders go viral. when they're good, nobody notices or cares. they only become "obviously ai" retroactively when revealed. so all this criticism is more about tribal signaling than actual quality assessment.

to clarify, peace is not-even-nothing, if 'nothing' has immediately introduced yet another notion of you suspended in an empty, thingless ether where nothing exists.

someone asked me the other day,

"if your state of mind is so good, why doesn't it reflect in your writing?"

well, because i'm not a sri sri charlatan selling a movie-brained song-and-dance idea of peace.

the only real thing that exists is your state of mind right now. you can only start here, nowhere else; you can only understand the nature of suffering, never the nature of peace, for peace is just the absence of suffering. it is nothing. you can't imagine it.
chasing peace is impossible. you don't know what it looks like, and whatever you're imagining it to be isn't real and is actually hindering you.
how can you chase peace when you don't even know what suffering looks like? someone told you that you can be more peaceful and less anxious, and you're now living with that idea.

meditation and spirituality as a whole is one of the most movie-brained notions you can find. and it primarily has to do with the fact that the questions they pose are entirely borrowed and not your own. they have to arise naturally when you see the nature of your suffering

cctv lagaao ghar mein aur record karo khud ko ek week ke liye. phir recording dekho dhyaan se. pata chal jaayega kitna "potential" hai

it'll be much more useful than any longform content you'll find on the internet.

the entire 'moral panic' around shortform video is itself dishonest slop. it's the equivalent of chichas sitting around a carrom board discussing china's foreign policy. bakaiti pro max. it has no real grounding in your life.

no one thinks of thinking as consumption, but a large proportion of it is merely frantic, broken regurgitation at a rapid clip. it's recycled fragments, ear worms and random song lyrics, imaginary arguments, half-formed anxieties. it's not like you're sitting there having profound 45-minute internal lectures. most thinking is choppy, repetitive, low-effort.

shortform content feels so native to us because it's actually mirroring the natural tendency of the mind. heck, twitter itself can attribute a lot of its success to this tendency.

so, to imagine your thoughts as this deep, contemplative river is a fanciful notion at best. you're mostly scrolling through your own mental feed of nonsense.

"longform" thinking is best done via writing or reading challenging texts, and how many of you actually write or read? it happens when you actually sustain focus on one idea, to gradually build something coherent.

so this idea of social media being an addictive slop fest that's preventing you from being great is just as delusional as the idea of your "potential".

it's copium.

you blame phones for shortening your attention span, but maybe your attention span was always kind of shit because you don't natively care about anything and have no intense interests that you're genuinely invested in that pull you away from divesting your energy and attention in these apps.
